title: Swiss Job Tracker
text:
Signs that the Swiss job market has passed its peak







Job market monitoring




New types of weekly job market data suggest that the big boom that has characterized the job market so far in 2022 may be fading. The new job indices, which will be updated every Friday from now on, show that the number of all jobs advertised online in Switzerland in mid-November was around 5% lower than in mid-October.






Nov 16, 2022


Daniel Kopp, Michael Siegenthaler, Severin Thöni






  




Swiss Job Tracker 1.0 released







Project News




Today, we launch swissjobtracker.ch. The dashboard provides and visualizes new weekly indices that measure how the near-universe of unique online job postings develop in Switzerland. The job indices can be broken down by industry, broad occupation, and canton.






Aug 18, 2022


Matthias Bannert, Jeremias Klaeui, Daniel Kopp, Michael Siegenthaler, Severin Thöni

title: Signs that the Swiss job market has passed its peak
text:
Swiss Job Tracker is a new type of job market index for Switzerland that is updated weekly. It tracks the development of all job postings advertised on company websites and job portals in Switzerland. At the end of the second week of November, the weekly job market index for the overall economy currently stood at 160 index points. This index value means that 60% more jobs were advertised on November 11 than in January 2020 - i.e., shortly before the outbreak of the Corona pandemic, which serves as the reference point for the index.
While the situation on the Swiss job market thus remains very good, the new real-time index indicates a slight deterioration in the labor market situation in the last few weeks. In mid-October, the index value had still been 168 points. Overall, the number of all jobs advertised online thus decreased by around 5% in one month. On the one hand, the decline is probably a sign of the deteriorating Swiss economy. On the other hand, the fact that there is typically less demand for personnel in November than in October due to the shoulder season in the tourism industry plays a certain role.



Swiss job tracker: Unique job postings in Switzerland


All data of the index can be viewed and downloaded on the website www.swissjobtracker.ch. The data will henceforth be published every week. The data basis and the calculation method of the indicator are described in detail here. Swiss Job Tracker and the new indices of job openings for Switzerland were created as part of the project “What Workers Want: Determinants and Implications of Job Search Strategies on an Online Job Platform” within the Swiss National Science Foundation’s (SNSF) National Research Program on “Digital Transformation” (NRP-77). The dashboard resulted from a collaboration between members of the KOF Swiss Economic Institute of ETH Zurich and the University of Lausanne. We thank x28 AG for data provision and support in constructing the indices.

title: Swiss Job Tracker 1.0 released
text:
Today, we present the first release of swissjobtracker.ch. The website is a new dashboard with labor market indicators that allow monitoring the Swiss labor market in real time. For this purpose, the dashboard provides and visualizes new high-frequency time series derived from large-scale online data sources. Users of the dashboard can generate figures of the time series, download the figures and the data, and access the complete source code of the dashboard.
Along this dashboard we release new and unique indicators on the state of the online job market in Switzerland. The indices measure how the number of unique online job postings in Switzerland change over time. The job indices can be broken down by industry, broad occupation, and canton. A central asset of these indices is the fact that we publish them on a weekly basis. Hence, the new job indices allow monitoring the state of the Swiss job market at a very high temporal frequency. The Covid crisis clearly showcased how important it is to have timely indicators of labor market activity.
The data used to construct these indices cover the near-universe of job postings in Switzerland published on job boards and firm websites. These data are collected by the private company x28 AG. x28 is specialized in collecting and synthesizing data from online job openings posted in Switzerland. Due to the importance of the online job market (Buchmann et al. 2022), the data cover close to 4 out of 5 job openings in Switzerland. Consequently, there exists a close correspondence between our new index of unique online job openings and the official vacancy index published by the Federal Statistical Office (see Figure below). Our indices also evolve similarly to those of official statistics in individual industries. However, our indices are published at a higher frequency and in real-time. While the indices cover a large number of job openings in all Swiss regions, the coverage of the German-speaking part may be slightly better than the coverage of the Latin-speaking parts of the country. A documentation that explains our new indices and shows how they compare with data from official statistics can be found here.



Correlation between our the new weekly index of unique online job postings and the official vacancy index of the Federal Statistical Office (BESTA)


Swiss Job Tracker and the new indices of job openings for Switzerland were created as part of the project “What Workers Want: Determinants and Implications of Job Search Strategies on an Online Job Platform” within the Swiss National Science Foundation’s (SNSF) National Research Program on “Digital Transformation” (NRP-77). The dashboard resulted from a collaboration between members of the KOF Swiss Economic Institute of ETH Zurich and the University of Lausanne. We thank x28 AG for data provision and support in constructing the indices.




References

Buchmann, Marlis, Helen Buchs, Felix Busch, Simon Clematide, Ann-Sophie Gnehm, and Jan Müller. 2022. “Swiss Job Market Monitor: A Rich Source of Demand-Side Micro Data of the Labour Market.” European Sociological Review, January. https://doi.org/10.1093/esr/jcac002.
